START: ^Okay, I need you to try and relax.
^You find yourself unable to move as this woman stares down at you. Has she strapped you down?
^You want me to relax? Are you serious?! How am I supposed to relax right now?!
^I know, I know. Just try, okay? This is only gonna hurt more if you’re tense.
^Hurt…? What are you doing that’s gonna hurt?! I thought I was getting exiled to Earth…
^You are. I’m only here to fraction your chip before they send you off.
^It’s just to limit your abilities while you’re among the Earthlings.
^We won’t leave you with nothing, that’d just be cruel. But we do take precautions like this to weaken you before you’re sent away.
^It’ll be like having half of a chip.
^That’s sick… Please, you can’t do this to me. I didn’t do anything wrong!
^We both know that’s not true. I’m sorry, but I’m just doing my job.
^Now seriously, you need to stop tensing up this much…

s: ^Yeah, right. You try relaxing while someone’s trying to rip your chip out.
^Tell me what you’re doing, then. And be specific!
^I’m trying my best, okay? I’m too stressed out to relax right now…

c-0: ^Okay well, that’s a little vulgar. It’s more nuanced than that.
^Fractioning isn’t “ripping a chip out,” it’s more like severing it and storing the removed components in a safe location while you’re away.
^Which for you… is most likely indefinitely.
c-1: ^I’m very thoroughly trained to work with people’s chips. Fractioning is no exception.
^I just extract the portion of the chip that I’m assigned to remove, and then it’s stored safely here at The Haevan while you get exiled down to Earth.
^Now please calm down so I can do this…
c-2: ^I understand, this must be a lot for you.
^I assure you, I am a trained professional. You have nothing to be worried about, okay? Just try and take deep breaths.
g-0: ^The woman rests a hand on your chest as a bright mix of yellow and blue glow around the contact. You feel a sharp, brutally painful sensation as the glow gets stronger and stronger. From the looks of it, the woman is experiencing the same pain.

^The lights begin to die down as you feel a powerlessness beginning to seep into your muscles. The procedure has certainly left you weaker than you have ever been before. As the pain subsides, you try to move and fight back, but find yourself mentally and physically incapable.
^Anthony, you can come back in now and take her away.

^You feel a grip on your arms similar to the one that brought you into this operation room earlier. Weakness continues to settle into your muscles, and your consciousness is fading quickly. When did you even get unstrapped from the table?
^Yes. She'll need time to recuperate from the operation, and then she'll be fine.
^Consider yourself lucky you’ll have such an easy passenger.
^The rest of your journey to Earth was hazy as your mind and body alike continue to give out on you. There is no more fighting back, you’re headed to Earth.

c-1: ^Um… You looked like you were sleeping in the middle of Sweetlake Forest. I get enjoying the scenery and all, but today really isn’t the best day to do that.

c-0: ^Yup! Practically the middle of nowhere, but it’s close enough to my house that I like to take walks here sometimes.

c-2: ^Good, I’m glad. You had me worried for a second there!
g-0: ^Are you not from around here or something? I don’t think I’ve ever seen you before.
^Yeah, you could say I’m from pretty far away.
^Today’s not the day to be sleeping in the middle of the woods. I don't know if you've heard, but they're predicting lots of rain in a bit. You should probably head home soon.

s: ^I don’t have a home I can go back to.
^I think I’d rather stay in the rain than go home.

c-0: ^Oh, well… I’m sorry to hear that.
c-1: ^Hah, I can understand that. Rain can be real nice to help get away from it all.
c-2: ^You caught me! Maybe it makes me a little strange, but I love walking in the rain. Something about it really helps me calm down.
g-0: ^I don’t want to leave you alone in a rainy forest though, so why don’t you come back to my house to wait out the storm? It’s not far from here, I’ll lead the way!

WELCOME: ^You’re back before the rain even started, that’s so unlike you. Who’s this?
^, I met her out in the forest. She needs a spot to crash and wait out the storm.

s: ^Thank you for letting me stay here.

c-0: ^Hahaha, thanks dude. You're not too bad yourself.
c-2: ^You seem shy, I promise I don’t bite. You don’t have to be all formal about thanking us, you know? It’s whatever.
g-0: ^Well, I’m gonna go get dinner started. I’ll let you guys chat and get you when we’re ready to eat.

JackeTalk: ^Hey, I’ve never been one for boring conversations. What do you say we play video games instead? Kill some time before dinner?

s: ^Sure, sounds like fun! But you’d have to teach me how.
^Think we could talk a bit first?
^Is it just you and Charlie that live here?
^How about we play that game now?

c-0: ^I don't see how that's any of your business.
c-1: ^Hey, it’s not my place to pry into your personal life. If you really wanna tell me then go for it, but you don’t have to.

c-0: ^ I’m from another planet, but I’m in pretty big trouble. I was exiled here earlier today, and your brother found me in the woods.
^Hahaha, I didn’t know you had such a sense of humor. Maybe you’re not so bad after all.

c-2: ^What, in Ember City? It’s fine I guess. City living isn’t that bad when you live on the outskirts of town like Charlie and I do.
c-3: ^You'll have to teach me how though!
^Oh, a woman after my own heart! You are SO on!

not_ready: ^Charlie is preparing dinner for the three of you. He seems pretty locked in.
ready: ^Thank you for including me in dinner.
^Of course! It’s no problem at all.
^So Ashley, I know you mentioned you were from pretty far away. Where are you from, anyway?
^If I told you, I don't think you would believe me…
^Why not? Are you like… from another country or something?
^Is this a joke or something? I don’t get it…
^I’m not joking! I’m from The Haevan, it’s another planet where humans live. I know Earthlings don’t really learn about us, but-
^That doesn’t make any sense. Why are you lying to us?
^Are you crazy or something? Charlie, did you bring a psycho into our house?
^Maybe this was a mistake… Look, I’m not gonna kick you out into the storm, but you can’t stay here. You’re kinda freaking us out.
^I’ll pack a container of food for you and I’ll write down the address of a shelter not too far from here, okay?
^Wait, I’m not trying to freak you out! I’m being serious!
^Be grateful I’m packing you food, okay? I’ve been awfully nice to you considering you’re a stranger from the woods who’s telling crazy stories to dodge questions about where you’re from…
WAIT: ^I’m sorry, that was rude of me to kick you out so fast… I’ll help you get to the shelter.
AFTERFIGHT: ^Phew… How… How did you do all that?! You were so fast, I don’t understand.
^Now you must believe me. I’m not from here, I’m from The Haevan.
^I’m serious! I’m sure you have questions, and I’m happy to answer them.

s: ^So, what is your talent then? Speed?
^This doesn’t make any sense. We didn’t even know that alien life existed, let alone ones that are so similar to humans.
^Do you have any idea what that thing was?
^Okay, I guess I kinda have to believe you now.

c-0: ^It’s another planet where humans live, and everyone that lives there has their own implants that give them specific talents.
c-1: ^…For simplicity’s sake, sure. It’s a little more nuanced than that, at least in my case, but yeah.
c-2: ^I am human, Charlie, everyone from The Haevan is. And Earthlings don’t know about us because your technology hasn’t advanced like ours has. You guys barely even have space travel!
c-3: ^I wish I did, but no. I’ve never seen anything like this before. I won’t lie, it’s pretty scary.
g-0: ^Phew… Thank you. I’m sorry you had to deal with all this. I’ll go, I don’t want to put you in any more danger.
^Hold on, you don’t have to go. I was quick to judge you, and I’m sorry. You’ve gotta admit it seems hard to believe.
^I knew the Earthlings didn’t know about us, but you’re right, I didn’t consider just how hard it might be to convince one of them that we’re real. You all seem kinda stubborn, huh?
^Gee… Thanks. Look, if those things come back, I don’t want you out here on your own. And I definitely don’t want them coming after us without you around. I can’t put Jacke in that kind of danger!
^Please, come back to the house. You can stay with us as long as you want.
^Really? Thank you so much! I really appreciate it.
^Of course. Now let's get out of this storm before that thing wakes up.
